flow.context: Robin Craigen is Co-Founder and CEO of Moving Mountains, a luxury vacation rental management company running 250 high-end homes across Steamboat Springs, Vail, Beaver Creek, and Breckenridge, CO. He's the strategic leader who publicly champions culture, selective hiring, and luxury benchmarks like privacy and hyper-personalization. The company just took investment from StayTerra (May 2025), acquired Triumph Mountain Properties (Dec 2023), and is actively scaling with pressure to standardize QA across four markets — they run on Track PMS and Breezeway, with dedicated QA inspector roles in every market. They promise owners detailed prearrival and post-stay inspections, bi-annual maintenance inspections, and asset protection — these are operational deliverables where misses cost owners. Sam's hook: he just skied Jackson Hole last month and has been working with luxury property managers in Colorado ski country.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Robin — so I was just out at Jackson Hole last month skiing, and I've been spending a bunch of time with luxury property managers in Colorado ski country. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet on desk energy. The skiing connection is real — Sam was at Jackson Hole Jan 2026. Robin lives and breathes Colorado ski resort country. Sound like a peer calling a peer, not a vendor pitching a CEO. Pause and let him respond.

branches.label: I'm in the middle of something / bad timing

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, use it to transition into discovery or pain. Don't correct anything — just flow with it.

branches.label: Vague or not sure what they heard

heard_no.label: HEARD NO
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call is —
heard_no.note: Self-deprecating, light, one second of a laugh. Immediately transition into the pain trigger without pausing. The dash at the end means you roll right into the next node.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday?
bad_timing.note: Don't push. Suggest two specific days. If he gives a time, lock it in. If he softens and asks what this is about, pivot to the pain trigger.

branches.label: Sure — try me Thursday / gives a time

reschedule.label: RESCHEDULE LOCKED
reschedule.say: Perfect — I'll try you then. Really appreciate it, Robin. Talk soon.
reschedule.note: Write down the exact day and time immediately. Don't pitch anything else. Keep it under five seconds and hang up.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION ASK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be upfront about that. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Disarm with honesty. Calling it a cold call actually builds trust because no telemarketer would ever say that. Smile while you say it.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you've already got this handled and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This split gives him an easy out while reopening the door. Most people pick bad timing, which lets you reschedule. If he says both, lean into the timing angle.

branches.label: Bad timing — try me another day
Wait — what is this actually about?

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Robin? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Say it like you know him. First name only for both of you. No company name, no title, no explanation. Pause and let them respond.

branches.label: Who is this / what's it about?

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other luxury property managers out in Colorado ski country. Would you mind letting Robin know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still no product pitch. Just enough context to sound legitimate and relevant. End with a redirect question so you stay in control.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally get it — we help a couple other property management companies with their inspection workflows. I actually sent Robin a note — would you mind giving him a heads up that Sam Parks called?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Last attempt. If they still block, ask for a good callback time or leave a voicemail. Don't fight the gatekeeper — they always win.

branches.label: Takes a message / suggests callback time

gatekeeper_voicemail.label: VOICEMAIL
gatekeeper_voicemail.say: Hey Robin — it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. I've been working with a few luxury property managers in Colorado ski country on their inspection workflows and wanted to connect. I'll try you again later this week — or you can grab me at [your number]. Talk soon.
gatekeeper_voicemail.note: Under 20 seconds. Casual, not scripted. Say your phone number slowly and clearly at the end. Don't sell anything. The goal is name recognition for when you call back.

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I've been working with another luxury PM CEO — actually pretty similar setup to you guys. Around 200 homes, multiple ski markets, dedicated QA inspectors, the works. And what he kept running into was that even with great people and a solid process, stuff was still slipping through at scale. A stain on a ten-thousand-dollar sofa goes unnoticed, a piece of art disappears between stays and nobody catches it for weeks, a home they just onboarded from an acquisition doesn't match the standard the owner was promised. And at the luxury level, one of those misses doesn't just hurt a review — it can cost you an owner.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE HERE. Do NOT jump to the solution. Let Robin react to this. The silence after the pain is where the magic happens. You just described HIS world back to him — 250 luxury homes, multiple markets, QA teams, acquisitions, owner expectations. Let it land.

branches.label: Engages — yeah that's real / tells his own story
Listening but noncommittal — okay so what do you do?
We already have Breezeway for that
Not really a problem for us / not interested

warm_response.label: WARM — STOP PITCHING
warm_response.say: Yeah that's exactly what I keep hearing. Out of curiosity — with 250 homes across four markets now, and especially after bringing the Triumph portfolio on board — how are you guys thinking about keeping QA consistent as you scale?
warm_response.note: He's engaged. DO NOT PITCH. Ask questions. Referencing 250 homes, four markets, and the Triumph acquisition shows you know his business — not from Google, from actually caring. Let him talk about his world.

branches.label: Opens up about growth pains / challenges
Delegates — that's more of a Chad or Lisa question

discovery_ceo.label: CEO DISCOVERY
discovery_ceo.say: That makes sense. And with the StayTerra investment — are you looking at standardizing any of the ops tooling across the portfolio, or is that more of a next-year conversation?
discovery_ceo.note: This is a CEO-level strategic question. You're asking about his roadmap, not his daily workflow. StayTerra invested in them May 2025 — this is live and relevant. If he opens up about tech investments or standardization plans, that's your lane. If he names specific people who own it, get those names.

branches.label: We're pretty set with what we have

discovery_tools.label: TOOLS DISCOVERY
discovery_tools.say: Oh nice — so you're running Breezeway for the field ops side. How's that been working across all four markets? Are your QA teams pretty dialed in on photo documentation, or is that still a moving target?
discovery_tools.note: You KNOW they use Breezeway and Track. Asking casually shows expertise without sounding like you stalked them. Listen for pain: photo volume, review bottleneck, inconsistency across Steamboat vs Vail vs Breck. That's where RapidEye fits.

branches.label: It works but there are gaps / photo review is painful
It's working great, we're happy with it
Mentions a specific pain or frustration
Delegates — talk to Lisa or Liz about that

one_sentence_solution.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
one_sentence_solution.say: So what we built — RapidEye plugs directly into Breezeway and Track, and it automatically analyzes the photos your QA team's already taking. Flags damage, missing items, staging issues — stuff that's easy to miss when you're reviewing hundreds of photos across four markets. No workflow change at all for your people.
one_sentence_solution.note: One breath. Mentioning Breezeway and Track by name shows you know their stack and this isn't a generic pitch. Don't oversell. Don't list features. Immediately move to the CTA.

branches.label: We already have Breezeway for that

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to taking a look? I could walk you through what it actually looks like inside Breezeway — not while I'm cold calling you, but maybe 15 minutes later this week?
cta_meeting.note: Low friction. 15 minutes, not 30. 'Not while I'm cold calling you' is disarming and honest. If he says yes, go straight to booking. Don't keep selling.

branches.label: I'd want Chad or Lisa on that call
No budget for new tools right now

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — I mean with dedicated QA teams in every market, you'd kind of have to have this dialed in already. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that this isn't really a problem you're focused on right now, or is it more that you just hate cold calls?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Surprise him by not pushing back. Referencing their dedicated QA teams shows homework and gives him credit. The split separates 'wrong problem' from 'wrong channel' — very different conversations.

branches.label: It's the cold call / bad timing
We genuinely don't have this problem

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Especially with everything going on with the investment and the growth — I'm sure every new line item has to go through the ringer right now. Just so no one bugs you again — is it that budget for this kind of thing is completely locked, or is it more that anything new has to go through a whole approval process?
objection_no_budget.note: Referencing the StayTerra investment casually shows you understand their world. The split separates 'no money' from 'painful process' — those are completely different objections with different paths forward.

branches.label: It's the approval process / takes forever
Wait — what does it actually cost?

objection_have_breezeway.label: OBJECTION — WE HAVE BREEZEWAY
objection_have_breezeway.say: Oh yeah — Breezeway's great for the workflow side, we actually plug right into it. So we're not replacing Breezeway at all. Your QA team takes photos in Breezeway like they always do — and RapidEye automatically analyzes those photos and flags anything that looks off. Damage, missing items, stuff that changed since last stay. Breezeway tells your team what to do. We tell them what to look for.
objection_have_breezeway.note: This is your most likely objection from someone who knows their stack. Be crisp: complementary, not competitive. The one-liner — 'Breezeway tells them what to do, we tell them what to look for' — is your closer. Pause after it.

branches.label: Oh that's different — tell me more
Interesting but not sure we need it
We'd need Lisa or Liz to evaluate that
We're good with what we have

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally respect that. You're probably not buying anything new today, and I get it. But here's what I've found — when budget does open up or priorities shift, the folks who move fastest are the ones who already know what's on the market. Would you be open to a quick look, even just so it's on your radar? Worst case you steal some ideas about what other luxury PMs are doing with their turnover photos and we part as friends.
sell_test_drive.note: You're not asking him to buy. You're asking him to be informed. 'Part as friends' is disarming and lowers the stakes. If he says yes, book it NOW — don't keep talking.

branches.label: Loop in my ops team instead

sell_test_drive_light.label: SOFTER VALUE OFFER
sell_test_drive_light.say: Totally fair. If nothing else, I could send you a quick breakdown of what other luxury PMs in ski country are doing with their inspection photos. No pitch attached — some of it's genuinely interesting. Would that be worth a look?
sell_test_drive_light.note: This is the softest possible CTA. Pure value, no strings. If he says yes, you have a reason to follow up with a warm email. If no, exit gracefully.

objection_send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
objection_send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most relevant to include so it's not just another generic vendor email sitting in your inbox?
objection_send_email.note: This does two things: gets him talking about his actual priorities (intel for you), and makes the follow-up actually useful to him. Whatever he says, tailor the email around it. Include a specific day/time suggestion in the email.

branches.label: Gives a specific topic or interest

email_confirm.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED
email_confirm.say: Perfect — I'll put something together and send it over today. Robin, really appreciate you taking my call. Talk soon.
email_confirm.note: Send the email within one hour. Reference something specific from this conversation. Include a calendar link and suggest a specific day and time for a 15-min call. Follow up in 3 business days if no reply.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — how does Tuesday or Wednesday look? I'm thinking early afternoon your time, maybe 1 or 2 PM Mountain?
book_meeting.note: Pick specific days and times. Don't say 'whenever works.' Send the calendar invite while you're still on the phone. If he wants to include Chad, Lisa, or someone from ops — even better, get their emails.

branches.label: Let me check and get back to you
I want to include my ops team

meeting_booked.label: MEETING LOCKED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — just sent the invite over. Really appreciate you taking my call, Robin. Looking forward to it.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. Meeting is booked. Send the invite right this second. Keep it warm, keep it short, and get off the phone. You won.

meeting_followup.label: MEETING — PENDING CONFIRM
meeting_followup.say: Totally — I'll shoot you an invite for Wednesday at 1 PM Mountain just to hold the spot. You can move it if you need to. Sound good?
meeting_followup.note: Always send the invite anyway. A calendar hold is way harder to ignore than a mental note. Follow up the morning of to confirm.

meeting_with_ops.label: MEETING — INCLUDE OPS
meeting_with_ops.say: Even better — would that be Chad or Lisa? I can send the invite to all of you. What's the best email for them?
meeting_with_ops.note: Getting Chad Rowe (COO) or Lisa Riniker (Director of Ops) on the call is ideal — that's where decisions get made. If he names someone else like Liz Piazza (Systems Admin), that's great too. Get emails right now while you have him.

branches.label: I'll loop them in on my end

referral_to_ops.label: REFERRAL — DELEGATES DOWN
referral_to_ops.say: That totally makes sense — at your level you're probably not in the weeds on inspection tooling day to day. Who on your team would typically own that decision? Is that more of a Chad thing or a Lisa thing?
referral_to_ops.note: You know Chad Rowe is COO and Lisa Riniker is Director of Ops. Dropping their names naturally shows you've done homework and makes Robin more comfortable connecting you. If he names someone else entirely, take it — Anna Calhoon (Housekeeping & QA Mgr) or Liz Piazza (Systems Admin) would be great too.

branches.label: Just email me and I'll forward it

get_referral_details.label: GET REFERRAL DETAILS
get_referral_details.say: Perfect. If I can get their direct email or number, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands and doesn't look like a random cold pitch. Would you be able to make a quick intro, or should I just reach out and mention we chatted?
get_referral_details.note: A warm intro from the CEO is gold. But even a 'mention my name' is 10x better than cold outreach to Lisa or Chad. Get the email or phone number right now while you have Robin on the line.

branches.label: I'll intro you — send me something to forward
Just reach out and use my name
Just send me the info and I'll pass it along

referral_confirmed.label: REFERRAL SECURED
referral_confirmed.say: Really appreciate that, Robin. I'll reach out to them this week and keep it tight. Thanks for taking my call — enjoy the rest of ski season.
referral_confirmed.note: End warm. The ski season closer is natural for a Steamboat Springs CEO in winter. Send the referral outreach within 24 hours, reference Robin by name in the first line, and tailor it to the specific person's role.

end_graceful.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
end_graceful.say: Totally understand, Robin. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time — enjoy the rest of ski season.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn this bridge. Robin is the CEO and co-founder — even if he's not buying today, he's the top of the org chart. You can always go direct to Chad, Lisa, or Anna next. Wait 3-6 months before trying Robin again.
